qas.question: When were young boys employed in the glass making industries?
Under glass making conditions were the children exposed to any heating elements?

answers.text: they are exposed to this heat

qas.question: Were the boys in glass making industry paid by the hour?
Did the glass industry have a preference for older working boys?

answers.text: factory owners preferred boys under 16 years of age

context: In the <a0_0>early 20th century<a0_0/>, thousands of boys were employed in glass making industries. Glass making was a dangerous and tough job especially without the current technologies. The process of making glass includes intense heat to melt glass (3133 °F). When the boys are at work, <a1_0>they are exposed to this heat<a1_0/>. This could cause eye trouble, lung ailments, heat exhaustion, cut, and burns. Since workers were <a2_0>paid by the piece<a2_0/>, they had to work productively for hours without a break. Since furnaces had to be constantly burning, there were night shifts from 5:00 pm to 3:00 am. Many <a3_0>factory owners preferred boys under 16 years of age<a3_0/>.
